question: Vide, Magister. There's something wrong. What's the matter? What's happened?
answer: I've just seen something. Something of consequence to you.

question: To me?
answer: Yes. My own death. Perhaps we had better hasten your training. This wood, these leaves, the birds, the very dome of heaven, once they all rang with one great chord

question: Of course.
answer: You have?

question: Well, almost.
answer: It's very difficult. Have you committed to memory undying the Codex de Profundis?

question: The first two chapters.
answer: It's long. And what about the Ritual of Banishment as prescribed by my late master Balisarius?

question: To tell the truth, I haven't dared try it. What's the point, anyway?
answer: The point? The point is you don't know it, and you're no magician without it. It was my hope to school you, to mold your faculties and wits... I still believe you have some talent. Somewhere.

question: I hate books. I hate drill. I want a real task.
answer: There's no time now. When I'm gone, half the powers in the universe will vanish with me. And what's the use of a few lingering skills if they're left in the hands of a child? Listen!

question: I don't hear anything.
answer: Here, wear this.

question: Voices, singing on the road. I don't see anything. He gawks skyward. Suddenly, the old man leans down and addresses him.
answer: We have visitors! Looks forbidding enough, don't you think?

question: Here are your sticks.
answer: No -- they'll think me infirm. You know, Balisarius wore this whenever he changed lead into gold. He could really do that, you know. I never could. Too bad -- you'd stand to inherit some real wealth.

question: You're in a morbid frame of mind. What's all this about dying? You don't even look sick.
answer: You still wearing that amulet? Good. Don't lose it. It still belongs to me. Now, adeptus minor, get yourself a handful of that sulphurous ash over there... Nunc habeus lux! Et calor! Welcome to Cragganmore. I am Ulrich. Which one of you calls himself Valerian?

question: You still wearing that amulet? Good. Don't lose it. It still belongs to me. Now, adeptus minor, get yourself a handful of that sulphurous ash over there... Nunc habeus lux! Et calor! Welcome to Cragganmore. I am Ulrich. Which one of you calls himself Valerian?
answer: That would be me. We are here on behalf...

question: I know why you're here. You're a delegation from Urland, from beyond Dalvatia. Let's see the artifacts.
answer: A bone. Scorched. A rock, fire- blackened. Scales.

question: All right. How did you come by these?
answer: I found them. At the mouth of the lair.

question: What else?
answer: A claw.

question: That's no claw. It's a tooth. By the gods! And you want me to do battle with that?
answer: Who else can we turn to? We all know what we're dealing with here. This is a basilicok. A cockatrice. A dragon. This is no stag, no bear, no natural creature. This is one of your kind. And only a necromancer such as yourself can rid us of it.

question: Did you try the Meredydd sisters? What about Rinbod? I've heard it said he killed a dragon once.
answer: They're all dead. You're the only one left.

question: It's a long way to Urland.
answer: Every quarter, upon the solstices and the equinoxes there's a new victim.

question: No. Sorcerers and dragons go back a long long time together. If it weren't for sorcerers, there wouldn't be any dragons. All right. I'll go. I know of this dragon. Vermithrax Pejorative While I'm gone see you keep your nose in your books and your hands out of my reagents. Leave my instruments alone too.
answer: Look at yourself. How far will you get like that? A league, two leagues?

question: I'm not worried about the road.
answer: Why don't you wave your hands around and summon up a coach-and-four?

question: Don't mock me.
answer: You pilgrims

question: What do you want with us?
answer: Well, like my good friends here, I've come for a bit of black magic. No doubt you've heard of our troubles at home. This is Cragganmore, is it not?

question: Aye, this be the place of Ulrich.
answer: And here we have the mystical presence himself, no?

question: You'd best keep your distance -- and your manners.
answer: If he's ready to lay a dragon in its grave, he's got nothing to fear from me. I've no more love for that creature than you lot. Nor has the King. But, before you stir things up, don't you think it a good idea to see you've got the right man for the job?

question: Aha -- it's a test you're looking for. We don't do tests.
answer: I'm sure you don't. They never do tests -- and not many real deeds either. Oh, conversation with your grandmother's shade in a darkened room, the odd love potion or two... but comes a doubter, well then, it's the wrong day, the planets are not aligned, the entrails aren't favorable, we don't do tests.

question: The erstwhile apprentice stands his ground, blinking back tears, his face weirdly illuminated by the fire. Hodge -- what are you doing?
answer: Just making my farewell, thank you very much. Be careful with that! You don't know what you're doing.

question: Stand back! Cragganmore! Domus non i am! Silva celet!
answer: Oh, it's a vale of tears in which we dwell. It doesn't matter who you are, a king in his robes, a peasant in his rags, when your time comes, no magic can save you...

question: I guess...
answer: ...the kindest lord a man could ask for... now he's gone. Ye gods he was fussy about his bath. And you'd think he could boil his own eggs with the snap of a finger, but no, he had old Hodge do it, of course. Up before five I was, mucking out the cages, slopping the pigs, and never once got so much as a thankyou or a pat on the back... I'm going to miss him.

question: Me too...
answer: No you don't. All you care about is the tricks and knavery. Well, you don't pull any wool over these old eyes. It'll be a mighty long walk before you fill his shoes, you mark my word.

question: What's the matter, Hodge, pack too heavy? Here.
answer: Careful with that!

question: Too cold, is it?
answer: Stop it!

question: Too warm?
answer: Stop it, I say! Out of respect for the master!

question: More the other way around, I'd say.
answer: What do you want?

question: A few words, that's all. You were looking for a conjurer.
answer: He's dead.

question: Call it proof, then.
answer: We've seen enough tests.

question: Well I haven't. All I've seen is death. Death in our families, death on the road, and tonight, death at home.
answer: What's come over you, anyway? Have you lost your wits?

question: I don't like it. Young snot-nose comes in here for sport at our expense. We're on a fool's errand, but we don't have to listen to this. I don't want to hear any more about sorcery. I don't want to hear any more about spells.
answer: You must be hungry.

question: Hodge marches along with the rest. When he's sure no one else is looking he burrows into his garments and brings out the leather pouch containing Ulrich's ashes. Reassured that it's still with him, he tucks it away again. Galen falls into step.
answer: What have you got there?

question: None of your business.
answer: A little gold, eh? What do you say I change it into lead?

question: Save your jokes for someone else. Me, I don't care for braggarts. And I don't care for frauds.
answer: I'm no fraud.

question: Call it fool then. Upstart. Whatever pleases you.
answer: Hodge, nobody forced you to come along.

question: Oh, I'm here of my own free will, all right. We each do the master's bidding in our own way.
answer: Well, if he told you I needed wetnursing, why don't you just turn yourself around and go back home.

question: Home, is it? You've seen to that, haven't you? Gone to seed, I'd say...
answer: He walks back along the trail, looking for Valerian. Pretty soon the rest of the travelers are out of sight. He hears the sound of a splash. He turns off the trail and pushes through some shrubbery. You're too far behind us. Come on out.

question: He walks back along the trail, looking for Valerian. Pretty soon the rest of the travelers are out of sight. He hears the sound of a splash. He turns off the trail and pushes through some shrubbery. You're too far behind us. Come on out.
answer: You go ahead, I'll catch up.

question: Not a good idea to get separated. Let's go.
answer: Right. I'll be along. That's all right. Don't come in. You better get back to the group, they're probably worried. I prefer to swim alone, if you don't mind.

question: By the gods!
answer: Stay away. I suppose you'll tell everyone. Go ahead, I don't care. It's a relief.

question: I'm not going to say anything.
answer: I don't blame you. I was stupid. Careless. A silly woman!

question: Take it easy. I knew the moment I saw you. I've known the whole time.
answer: You never knew a thing. No one knew. Not since I was born. Go on, run off and tell them. It'll make a great story.

question: Don't worry. No one's going to find out. Just tell me
answer: Ask my father.

question: The lottery! Daughters are chosen, but sons are not!
answer: That's right. Unless you have plenty of gold or property.

question: What do you mean?
answer: If you're rich enough, your name never goes in. My father is poor. So are a lot of fathers.

question: No! No! Hodge!
answer: Galen? Can you hear me?

question: I hear you.
answer: You know, somebody shot me, but I can still talk. There's something that has to be done.

question: I know.
answer: Not that cockatrice. Ulrich's ashes. Here. Take it. Sorry, you'll have to peel it loose. ...burning water... find the lake, throw it in...

question: What are you doing with this, Hodge?
answer: ...burning water...

question: Come on. Don't dawdle here.
answer: The whole kingdom like this?

question: No. We're near the lair. Keep moving.
answer: Where?

question: Over there. Doesn't matter. We're in no danger if we just pass through quickly.
answer: I see it. Let's have a look.

question: Welcome back, my son.
answer: Father, what are you doing? Have you all lost your minds?

question: Some have. It's this monk. He can read and write, and talk too, I'm afraid.
answer: And they listen?

question: Shh! They think this a holy place, a tabernacle.
answer: This is the granary. What kind of welcome is this? I've got news of the sorcerer and news of the dragon.

question: Put that away. What if you were seen?
answer: I'm going to be seen. I want to be seen. Tonight the world finds out that you never had a son.

question: No, you mustn't do that. It's too soon. We've got to think about this, we've got to make a plan.
answer: Father

question: I know. What am I going to say to my friends who still mourn for their lost girls.
answer: You'll say you did what you had to. This is a time for celebration -- and forgiveness.

question: The damnedest thing is, she was twice the man of anyone else in the village. Now she's twice the woman.
answer: Would that I had been as clever as her father.

question: Come now, Greil. Don't begrudge a life spared.
answer: I begrudge nothing. But I wonder at what we have seen and how it was done.

question: You were there.
answer: I saw what I saw. But this jack-anapes was barely ready to carry his master's chamberpot. Isn't it strange that at the very moment the beast is put down we should have a holy man here in the village?

question: You don't believe that superstitious Christian rot, do you?
answer: It is said God works his wonders in mysterious ways.

question: Don't worry. I'll be back. One of the best things about the water here in Urland is that there's so much of it -- look at that! Mmm. Good. But not cold enough. Perhaps I could borrow a scarf from his Majesty. I cover the goblet, so... remove, so... and behold All right. How many of you have ever seen a table fly?
answer: Enough! That's fine.

question: Wait, it'll rise now.
answer: Don't bother. Not necessary. Tell me

question: Yes.
answer: I see. And having rendered such unique service to our kingdom, what would you claim as a reward?

question: Please -- no payment. I have always found magical practice to be its own reward. I seek only some yet greater challenge.
answer: Did you ever hear of King Gaiseric? Of course not, you weren't even born. He was my brother, a great King and a valiant man-at-arms. When he ascended to the throne, the dragon was unbridled. No one knew where it might strike next. So he brought forth his broadsword and his spear, assembled a company of his best fighters and went out to do battle. He was never seen again. But his attack provoked the most terrible reprisals How did you arrogate to yourself the role of savior?

question: I was invited.
answer: Not by me. Did you ever consider the consequences of failure?

question: What failure? What's the matter with you people? You want the dragon back?
answer: Then the beast is dead?

question: Yes, of course. Dead.
answer: We shall see.

question: I've studied Latin. Greek, too. Me appelo Elspeth, filia regis.
answer: How do you do.

question: Please don't think ill of us. My father is a wonderful man, a wise man. The lottery was his idea.
answer: I see.

question: You don't understand. From the moment it began, the dragon was tame. The kingdom prospered.
answer: And only a few had to be sacrificed.

question: Yes, that's true. Isn't it better that a few should die that many might live?
answer: Depends on who does the dying.

question: Oh, but we all take our chances. My father is a just man. My name is entered on the lists, along with every other young --
answer: Virgin?

question: Maiden.
answer: If you say so.

question: What do you mean?
answer: Nothing.

question: I've participated in every drawing since I came of age.
answer: Maybe.

question: It's true. You don't believe me. You think I'm lying. Well I'm not.
answer: I'm sorry. I heard a rumor. Families with money, that sort of thing.

question: Don't listen to rumors. They're lies. I have to go now.
answer: Wait -- how long do I have to stay in here?

question: Until we know. Not long. Goodbye. Vale. Dormi bene.
answer: That's enough. Let's not be greedy here. Now then

question: Father?
answer: Not now. Tyrian, remove all but one bar. We'll try it one at a time.

question: Father
answer: Nonsense. By the power of this amulet, justly wielded by my hand in accordance with the laws of Urland, now lead be thou gold. I'm burned! What devilish thing is this?

question: Have you ever kept my name off the lottery list?
answer: That'll be all, Tyrian. You may withdraw. Now, my dear, what's troubling you?

question: Answer my question Well?
answer: Your father loves you very much.

question: It's true! What have you done to me!?
answer: Who fills your head with such ideas?

question: It's me. Are you hurt?
answer: Where have you been? Doesn't matter -- listen

question: I can't.
answer: Then get the animals back. They're all running loose. There's people been hurt. Stop their pain. You can cure them. And we'll need food...

question: I can't do it.
answer: What? Why not?

question: I just can't.
answer: But you're a sorcerer.

question: I'm no sorcerer. Whatever power I might have had, it's gone.
answer: It can't be!

question: I know
answer: You're sorry?! Listen to that! The damn thing is loose, we're all on fire and you're sorry! You didn't have the faintest idea what you were doing, did you? You're a fool -- and I'm a bigger one for bringing you here. I don't want you in this house. Get out.

question: As the proud new father of an eligible daughter who was some-how overlooked all these years, it may interest you to know that the King has called for a new lottery.
answer: But it's months til the solstice.

question: In view of what's happened, we all know what's required.
answer: I've never taken part in your cursed lottery, and I'll have nothing to do with it now.

question: You were very clever. But she'll take part, like all the rest. No exceptions.
answer: All right. I know what you want. How much?

question: Are you offering me a bribe?
answer: Yes.

question: Nothing's that sharp.
answer: The best I ever made.

question: It's beautiful.
answer: Don't do that! Girl-child, when you were born I knew I had to do something, so I set about the task of fashioning an extraordinary weapon

question: That's not the name. It's been misread.
answer: There's no mistake! The name's been chosen -- let it stand!

question: No, the good Horsrik has misspoke himself. In fairness to this individual, whose name I can't make out, we'll destroy this tile.
answer: No! What better name than your own kin? At last we see justice done!

question: An edge like no other on this earth.
answer: Well done, Simon. Thank you.

question: I'll say goodbye to Valerian for you. I'm sorry she's not here, but you know how she is.
answer: I understand.

question: Galen. Here. It's a shield. I made it. Might keep the fire off you. Might not. You know, you're an idiot. You're going to die tonight. You'll be ripped limb from limb. This is the last time I'll ever speak to you.
answer: Thank you.

question: Another thing. That thing isn't alone up there. There's little ones. Young, I think. I don't know how many.
answer: Hatchlings. They'll have to be killed too. Anything else?

question: You're in love, aren't you?
answer: Yes.

question: That's all right. I understand. She's very beautiful, very brave.
answer: Who is? What do you mean?

question: Your Princess. But I don't care. It doesn't change the way I feel. Listen to me, Galen Bradwardyn, sorcerer's apprentice; you're going to be dead, the dragon will be worse than ever, there will be more lotteries, and I'm not a boy any more.
answer: And you'll be eligible because --

question: Because I'm still a virgin, and I want you to do something about it.
answer: I am in love. But not with the Princess.

question: What's that?
answer: Nothing. I was just thinking -- poor Hodge.

question: How's your leg?
answer: Hurts. That thing was small, but its teeth were sharp.

question: At least you killed it. You got all the young.
answer: But the big one's alive. Somewhere down in that burning lake.

question: Don't think about it. You had your fight, and you're still here. That's more than anyone else can say. Let's think about what lies ahead.
answer: Galen has come to a halt in the middle of the path. He's staring into the middle distance with a sudden inspiration bubbling in his brain. He flings off his sack, drops to his knees and tears through the contents. Valerian comes back, baffled. Galen's gear is strewn all over the trail.

question: What are you doing?
answer: You old trickster! The burning water! The lake of fire!

question: Galen, what are you saying?
answer: He had it planned. He knew this was going to happen.

question: Who did? What happened?
answer: We've got to go back, I want to talk to him!

question: Galen, stop! Please, I beg you! Stop! I won't let you kill yourself.
answer: He couldn't walk -- he knew he couldn't make the journey. So he had us make the journey for him! Don't you see?

question: No! All right, all right. You're going in there, I'm going too.
answer: What? Why? No you're not, this is my job. Absolutely not.

question: I'm not afraid. And you're not going to stop me. After all -- I've been a man longer than you have.
answer: Stay close.

question: What's that?
answer: Never mind. Come on. All right. Wait here.

question: Galen? Galen? Where are you?
answer: Ex favilla, vita nova!

question: Ulrich! Magister! Over here! I can see you! Over here!
answer: Not so loud. I'm not deaf, you know. Sic redit magus ex terra mortis.

question: Wonder of wonders -- you're back! I thank the powers that made me!
answer: Glad to see you, too. You didn't bring along anything to eat, by any chance?

question: Food?
answer: No? Oh well, no time anyway. Come along. There's much to be done.

question: Wait, I have something to tell you.
answer: It can wait.

question: No it can't. Listen
answer: Well said. Now hurry.

question: Well said. Now hurry.
answer: Time seems to have come to a stop. Overhead, the moon is locked in front of the sun. At the lair, Valerian stands frozen as the dragon leans over her. The great head sways from side to side. The jaws hinge open. Suddenly, Valerian recovers herself and makes a run for it, leaping and scrabbling over the rocks. A plume of flame licks at her heels. She sees a protective crevice and heads for it, but a winged claw drops to block her way. She changes direction and is cut off again. Cat and mouse.

question: There is the sorcerer, leaning on Galen, coolly regarding the creature. The old man's expression hardens. Draco draconis...
answer: Galen!

question: Where's my amulet? Give it to me, please. Be quick! Come close to me. Don't be afraid. You have served me with great courage. Now you must show me you have even more.
answer: Anything!

question: You must destroy the amulet, and me along with it.
answer: No!

question: You brought me from the flames, you must send me back.
answer: I can't.
